trans-unit.source: Service Bus AMQP Overview
trans-unit.target: Service Bus AMQP Overview

trans-unit.source: Support for AMQP 1.0 in <token>sb1</token> means that it’s possible to leverage the queuing and publish/subscribe brokered messaging features of <token>sb2</token> from a range of platforms, using an efficient binary protocol.
trans-unit.target: Support for AMQP 1.0 in <token>sb1</token> means that it’s possible to leverage the queuing and publish/subscribe brokered messaging features of <token>sb2</token> from a range of platforms, using an efficient binary protocol.

trans-unit.source: You can also build applications that are comprised of components built using a mix of languages, frameworks, and operating systems.
trans-unit.target: You can also build applications that are comprised of components built using a mix of languages, frameworks, and operating systems.

trans-unit.source: This developer’s guide explains how to use the <token>sb2</token> brokered messaging features (queues and publish/subscribe topics) using .NET, Java, Python, and PHP via AMQP 1.0.
trans-unit.target: This developer’s guide explains how to use the <token>sb2</token> brokered messaging features (queues and publish/subscribe topics) using .NET, Java, Python, and PHP via AMQP 1.0.

trans-unit.source: AMQP is also supported in <token>sb_onprem</token>.
trans-unit.target: AMQP is also supported in <token>sb_onprem</token>.

trans-unit.source: <token>crdefault</token> <legacyLink xlink:href="409aa385-2784-4d38-a23d-c8e400b54360" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Using Service Bus for Windows Server from Java with AMQP 1.0</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: <token>crdefault</token> <legacyLink xlink:href="409aa385-2784-4d38-a23d-c8e400b54360" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Using Service Bus for Windows Server from Java with AMQP 1.0</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: The following diagram illustrates an example deployment in which Java clients that run on Linux, written using the standard Java Message Service (JMS) API, and .NET clients that run on Windows, exchange messages via <token>sb2</token> using AMQP 1.0.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram illustrates an example deployment in which Java clients that run on Linux, written using the standard Java Message Service (JMS) API, and .NET clients that run on Windows, exchange messages via <token>sb2</token> using AMQP 1.0.

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 technical features
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 technical features

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 is an efficient, reliable, wire-level messaging protocol that you can use to build robust, cross-platform, messaging applications.
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 is an efficient, reliable, wire-level messaging protocol that you can use to build robust, cross-platform, messaging applications.

trans-unit.source: The protocol has a simple goal: to define the mechanics of the secure, reliable, and efficient transfer of messages between two parties.
trans-unit.target: The protocol has a simple goal: to define the mechanics of the secure, reliable, and efficient transfer of messages between two parties.

trans-unit.source: The messages themselves are encoded using a portable data representation that enables heterogeneous senders and receivers to exchange structured business messages at full fidelity.
trans-unit.target: The messages themselves are encoded using a portable data representation that enables heterogeneous senders and receivers to exchange structured business messages at full fidelity.

trans-unit.source: The following is a summary of the most important features:
trans-unit.target: The following is a summary of the most important features:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Efficiency</embeddedLabel>: AMQP 1.0 is a connection-oriented protocol that uses a binary encoding for the protocol instructions and the business messages transferred over it.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Efficiency</embeddedLabel>: AMQP 1.0 is a connection-oriented protocol that uses a binary encoding for the protocol instructions and the business messages transferred over it.

trans-unit.source: It incorporates sophisticated flow-control schemes to maximize the utilization of the network and the connected components.
trans-unit.target: It incorporates sophisticated flow-control schemes to maximize the utilization of the network and the connected components.

trans-unit.source: That said, the protocol was designed to strike a balance between efficiency, flexibility and interoperability.
trans-unit.target: That said, the protocol was designed to strike a balance between efficiency, flexibility and interoperability.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Reliability</embeddedLabel>: The AMQP 1.0 protocol enables messages to be exchanged with a range of reliability guarantees, from fire-and-forget to reliable, exactly-once acknowledged delivery.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Reliability</embeddedLabel>: The AMQP 1.0 protocol enables messages to be exchanged with a range of reliability guarantees, from fire-and-forget to reliable, exactly-once acknowledged delivery.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Flexibility</embeddedLabel>: AMQP 1.0 is a flexible protocol that can be used to support different topologies.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Flexibility</embeddedLabel>: AMQP 1.0 is a flexible protocol that can be used to support different topologies.

trans-unit.source: The same protocol can be used for client-to-client, client-to-broker, and broker-to-broker communications.
trans-unit.target: The same protocol can be used for client-to-client, client-to-broker, and broker-to-broker communications.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Broker model-independence</embeddedLabel>: The AMQP 1.0 specification does not enforce any requirements on the messaging model used by a broker.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Broker model-independence</embeddedLabel>: The AMQP 1.0 specification does not enforce any requirements on the messaging model used by a broker.

trans-unit.source: This means that it’s possible to easily add AMQP 1.0 support to existing messaging brokers.
trans-unit.target: This means that it’s possible to easily add AMQP 1.0 support to existing messaging brokers.

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 is a standard
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 is a standard

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 has been in development since 2008 by a core group of more than 20 companies, both technology suppliers and end-user firms.
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 has been in development since 2008 by a core group of more than 20 companies, both technology suppliers and end-user firms.

trans-unit.source: During that time, user firms have contributed their real-world business requirements and the technology vendors have evolved the protocol to meet them.
trans-unit.target: During that time, user firms have contributed their real-world business requirements and the technology vendors have evolved the protocol to meet them.

trans-unit.source: Throughout the process, vendors have participated in connect-a-thon workshops where they’ve collaborated to validate interoperability between their implementations.
trans-unit.target: Throughout the process, vendors have participated in connect-a-thon workshops where they’ve collaborated to validate interoperability between their implementations.

trans-unit.source: In October 2011, the development work was transitioned to a technical committee within the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS) and the OASIS AMQP 1.0 Standard was released in October 2012.
trans-unit.target: In October 2011, the development work was transitioned to a technical committee within the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS) and the OASIS AMQP 1.0 Standard was released in October 2012.

trans-unit.source: The following firms participated in the technical committee during the development of the standard:
trans-unit.target: The following firms participated in the technical committee during the development of the standard:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Technology vendors</embeddedLabel>: Axway Software, Huawei Technologies, IIT Software, INETCO Systems, Kaazing, Microsoft, Mitre Corporation, Primeton Technologies, Progress Software, Red Hat, SITA, Software AG, Solace Systems, VMware, WSO2, Zenika.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Technology vendors</embeddedLabel>: Axway Software, Huawei Technologies, IIT Software, INETCO Systems, Kaazing, Microsoft, Mitre Corporation, Primeton Technologies, Progress Software, Red Hat, SITA, Software AG, Solace Systems, VMware, WSO2, Zenika.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>User firms</embeddedLabel>: Bank of America, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Boerse, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>User firms</embeddedLabel>: Bank of America, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Boerse, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase.

trans-unit.source: Some of the commonly cited benefits of open standards include:
trans-unit.target: Some of the commonly cited benefits of open standards include:

trans-unit.source: Less chance of vendor lock-in
trans-unit.target: Less chance of vendor lock-in

trans-unit.source: Interoperability
trans-unit.target: Interoperability

trans-unit.source: Broad availability of libraries and tooling
trans-unit.target: Broad availability of libraries and tooling

trans-unit.source: Protection against obsolescence
trans-unit.target: Protection against obsolescence

trans-unit.source: Availability of knowledgeable staff
trans-unit.target: Availability of knowledgeable staff

trans-unit.source: Lower and manageable risk
trans-unit.target: Lower and manageable risk

trans-unit.target: Using Service Bus for Windows Server from Java with AMQP 1.0
